title: A French Game Wins Big at The Game Awards
summary: Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 is a French role-playing game that won Game of the Year at The Game Awards. It got nine awards out of ten categories it was in, including best story, music, and performance. The game is about adventurers trying to stop a supernatural being called The Paintress, who stops people from growing old. Players liked the emotional story and turn-based battles. The developers left a big company to make their dream game. At the awards, the director thanked his team and people who make game tutorials online. The game was the most nominated ever with twelve nods. Its composer won for best music, and an actress won for best performance, dedicating it to neurodivergent people.

background_read: The Game Awards is a big event where video games are celebrated and given prizes each year. Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 is a role-playing game made in France, where players control characters in a fantasy world. The developers, Sandfall Interactive, started their own company after working at a larger game maker. The game features a story about fighting a magical being and uses old-style gameplay where players take turns in battles. Awards like best music and performance recognize the people who create the sounds and act in the game.
Article_Structure: WHO: The developers Sandfall Interactive, director Guillaume Broche, composer Lorien Testard, and actress Jennifer English.
WHAT: Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 won Game of the Year and eight other awards at The Game Awards.
WHERE: The awards ceremony was in Los Angeles.
WHY: The game was praised for its emotional story, turn-based battles, and the developers' journey to make their dream project.

perspectives.description: The game's big win shows how a small team can achieve recognition in the gaming industry.
